item.content:encoded:
Free Udemy courses, Next Level

In my last post I told you about how I managed to pull out udemy course URLs, but still clicking from a text file can be pretty tough if it contains ~500 links per day, then What to do ü§î
üëâ HTML and mouse automation

Get ready for the Magic

You may be wondering why didn‚Äôt I use web-drivers and selenium for automation, trust me I did but the results where absolutely worthless, I spend hours on selenium and google web-driver but the links always opens in a sand box hence, udemy detects it and logouts you and its protected by a capta Here is where the good old mouse automation helps us.but how to make links click able üôã
üëâ make a html out of it.

file = open("/home/antony/Code/Telegram/urls.html", "w") 
    file.write("<html><head></head><body>")
    for url in udemy_url:
        if(not(url in lines)):
            try:
                file.write(f'<a href="{url}"> {url} </a> <br>') 
            except:
                pass
    file.write("</body></html>")
    file.close()

this is the exact code I used.üëç

after that it all ‚Äúpyautogui‚Äù these are packages required to start

import pyautogui 
import os
import time

get all important screen points by using:

print(pyautogui.size())
print(pyautogui.position())

then point the mouse to the first URL increment step size (step = 17), then the process gets tricky when the last URL in the screen is reached hence we use the scroll function to scroll to the next block of URLs.

for _ in range(15):
        pyautogui.click(x_scroll, y_scroll)

after you click a URL using pyautogui.click(x_inital, y_inital) then find the enroll button in the screen od udemy hence we can do something like this pyautogui.click(x_enroll, y_enroll) don‚Äôt forget to time.sleep(10) as it takes time to load the website or a click will be wasted.

there you have it, all udemy URL in HTML and auto mouse clicking.

If you want to go a little further incorporate a mouse click task using python threading so that you don‚Äôt need to change screen timeout and don‚Äôt need to type in passwords on timeout.

x = threading.Thread(target=fake_mouse, args=(True,))
x.start()

item.content:encoded:
Free Udemy courses, no Hoax

Many Telegram channels provide udemy courses for free, but the problem is looking through ~500 pages for udemy URLs can be daunting. So what to do ü§î
üëâ ‚ÄúTELEGRAM API‚Äù, and a crawler üï∏ can do the job for you.

Get ready for the Magic

First, go to telegram API and register for a telegram App great thanks to @Dayal Chand Aichara he explains it vividly. From there we can get messages from telegram channels. The next step is to get Udemy channels in the telegram, the easiest method is just to search the Udemy in telegram. Voila Solved.‚úå make necessary changes to code and you will get the messages on an average the messages in these kinds of channels range from 80 - 100. so fix the message count appropriately If you want to put more count be my guest.üòú then use python regex to extract all the URLs from the messages.that is pretty simple:

re.findall(r'(https?://\S+)', str(message["content"]))

as we found all the URLs, next job is to categorize the URLs into different sites there are many sites which provide free courses, so head to the site get the Xpath of the ‚ÄúCLICK HERE‚Äù ‚Äòs then use selenium web driver to get the href within.

important point is that always use unquote to take care of URL encoding

from urllib.parse import unquote
unquote(URL)

store all those links in a text file and check if its not already present in text.

for url in udemy_url:
        if(not(url in lines)):
            try:
                file.write("\n"+url+"\n") 
            except:
                pass

there you have it, all udemy URL in a text file.

How to start to place emoji in gatsby

Let‚Äôs face it everyone likes emojis, and would like to include them in code, but how to do it. Well in gatsby it did like this :

npm install --save gatsby-remark-emoji

gatsby-remark-emoji which parses the code and replaces the emoji

npm install --save gatsby-remark-a11y-emoji

gatsby-remark-a11y-emoji which wraps the emoji into .üôà

It works after adding it to your gatsby-config.js file and this happened, Gatsby is üíØ now I can have as many emojis I want üòÉ

Now Lets Talk vs code.

which I liked the most is 

Emoji
perkovec.emoji

which help to insert the emoji from command palate üëè,

If you are wondering about snippets try prismjs

It works after adding it to your gatsby-config.js file, but I was just a bit disappointed by the default themes available. I like the one-monokai theme for VSCode. I wanted to use it for my code snippets on the blog. This was made possible thanks to @konnyakuxzy . just copy it in theme folder and require it in browser.js voila ‚ö°

item.content:encoded:
How to start a blog in 15 min

Start with cloning the gatsby gatsby-starter-blog Template üôà

git clone https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-blog.git

we got the template the next question is where to host, as hosting can be expensive and we are looking at a ~100-page static website. there is no need for hosting, here is where GitHub pages come to the rescue üî•. we will go in steps from now:

  1. Make a Github repo named username.github.io (this will be your domain) üåè
  2. Then make a remote with this repo from the cloned directory
  3. The tricky üé© part is that GitHub only allows the master branch to launch the site (which means gh-page package won‚Äôt work üò¢)

  4. Initialize git in the public directory in the cloned repo, not find anything run:

    npm run deploy

    and then

    cd public && git init

  5. but worry not I have found a work around

    "masterdeploy": `gatsby build && cd public && git add . 
&& git commit -m 'default' && git push origin master`

    add this to ‚Äúscripts‚Äù in package.json file.

  6. Make necessary changes to the repo to make it your own.

  7. run this in terminal

    npm run masterdeploy
  8. There is no step 8, You are all done

Happy blogging üòÉ

I will put customization I made in a later post stay tooned.

item.content:encoded:
This is my first post on my new blog! How exciting!

I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll write a lot more interesting things in the future.

I like to thank Kiran Anto, my senior in college who gave me the motivation to do so.

This Blog aims to Record all the small achievements of the day.

As in the book, Atomic Habits says Small changes compound to Big differences.

If You want to check out the book try Pdf-Drive

Pdf Drive.

Quotes from Atomic Habits

  1. You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fall to the level of your systems.
  2. We often dismiss small changes because they don‚Äôt seem to matter very much at the moment.
  3. Time magnifies the margin between success and failure. It will multiply whatever you feed it. > Good habits make time your ally. Bad habits make time your enemy.
  4. Decide the type of person you want to be. Prove it to yourself with small wins.
  5. It‚Äôs only by making the fundamentals of life easier that you can create the mental space needed > for free-thinking and creativity.
  6. Before we can effectively build new habits, we need to get a handle on our current ones.
  7. Standardize before you optimize. You can‚Äôt improve a habit that doesn‚Äôt exist.
